headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; JAPANESE. Our Relations with Japan--The Loe-Choo and Japanese Missions--Interesting Statement A Rich Sale. Teachers Meeting. Society of Inquiry-Union Theological Seminary.

docs.lead_paragraph: A meeting took place on Friday afternoon at the Mission room of the Methodist Episcopal Society in Mulberry-street, convened chiefly to listen to statements concerning the progress of Christianity in Lool Choo and Japan, from Rev. Dr. BETTELHEIM, who has been engaged since 1815 in missionary labor in that distant part of the world.

headline.main: NEW-JERSEY.; Hoboken Charter Vote--Official Result. Attempted Suicide. A Patent Safe Operation.
How the Poole Obsequies Struck the Country People.

NEW-YORK CITY.; MECHANICS' INSTITUTE LECTURES. James T. Brady on Social Life as Affected by Useful Inventions. FIRE DEPARTMENT. Lectures on Europe. American Institute Farmers' Club. Contranet for Lighting the Piers of the City Declared Void. Swearing in the City Hall. A Sliding Scale. The City Hall-Look out for Costly Abortions. Destructive Gas Explosion. Fire in Anthony-street. COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS. Beard of Alderman Investigation of Fires. FIRE IN BATTERY-PLACE. Street Sweeping--The New Machines.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES T. BRADY lectured before the Mechanics Institute, last evening, on "The Influence of Useful Inventions on Social Life." He complained that history had recorded the career of potentates and conquerors, but seldom transmitted the achievements or names of those who, by the arts of peace, promoted the welfare of mankind. We knew nothing of the great mechanics who reared the stupendous or beautiful architecture of Egypt, Greece, and Rome.

headline.main: LONG ISLAND.; Death of a Long Island Centenarian.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Several weeks since you published a notice of JOHN WOODHULL, Esq., a venerable centenarian of this vicinity. His funeral was attended on Friday last by a large concourse of his friends and neighbors. Several of the clergy of the adjacent parishes took part in the religious services.
